entry.title: B/R NFL 1,000: Top 50 Quarterbacks
entry.content: Who is the best quarterback in the NFL ? How many times have you debated that question? Arguing who is better between Aaron Rodgers , Tom Brady and even Drew Brees is enough to start a bar fight.

entry.title: 6 Movies Inadvertently Remade as Other Movies
entry.content: Apparently, there are movies, sometimes decades apart, that seem to have absolutely nothing to do with each other ... and yet, when you look at them carefully, they turn out to be the exact same thing.

entry.title: Racist imagery used to push for Minnesota voter ID law
entry.content: An online banner on WeWantVoterID.com, a site created by the conservative group Minnesota Majority, shows an African-American male dressed in a black-and-white-striped prison suit and a person dressed in a blue mariachi costume standing alongside fictional characters. All of the characters are lined up waiting to vote and the online banner’s reads” “Voter Fraud: Watch How Easy It Is To Cheat In Minnesota’s Elections.”

entry.title: Pinterest Allows Websites to Opt Out of Pinning
entry.content: Pinterest now allows companies and online publishers to block users from pinning pictures, images and content to virtual pinboards.

entry.title: Dead for 32,000 Years, an Arctic Plant Is Revived
entry.content: Living plants have been generated from the fruit of a little arctic flower, the narrow-leafed campion, that died 32,000 years ago, a team of Russian scientists reports. The fruit was stored by an arctic ground squirrel in its burrow on the tundra of northeastern Siberia and lay permanently frozen until excavated by scientists a few years ago.

entry.title: ‘Hundreds gather’ in China after monk’s self-immolation | The Raw Story
entry.content: Hundreds of Tibetans gathered in China’s southwest to hold a vigil for a young Buddhist monk who set himself on fire, a rights group said, in the latest self-immolation to hit the country.

entry.title: Scientists Launch Rocket Into Aurora
entry.content: A two-stage Terrier-Black Brant rocket arced through aurora 200 miles above Earth as the Magnetosphere-Ionosphere Coupling in the Alfvén resonator (MICA) mission investigated the underlying physics of the northern lights. Stage one of the rocket has just separated and is seen falling back to Earth.

entry.title: Swedish man trapped in snow-buried car survives for two months
entry.content: Just as news of several skiers being trapped and killed in the U.S. breaks, news coming from Sweden tells a slightly more positive story about a man believed to have been trapped in his car - possibly for as long as two months.

entry.title: Full List of Winners From the Writers Guild of America
entry.content: The Writers Guild of America gave out its annual awards on Sunday night, bestowing its hardware to the year's most accomplished film and television scribes. Here's your full list of winners.

entry.title: 'Tank' Purchase for Local Law Enforcement the Center of NH Furor [Video]
entry.content: New Hampshire residents in Keene have managed to block a plan by its council to purchase what was described by its Mayor Kendall Lane as a 'tank' The Lenco Industries BearCat G3 was set to be added to the local law enforcement fleet at a cost of $285,933, courtesy of a grant from the DHS.

entry.title: Swedish man survives in frozen car, at -30C, for two months by eating handfuls of snow
entry.content: Emaciated and barely able to speak, Peter Skyllberg, 44, was pulled from his vehicle having survived on nothing but snow for 60 days in drifts on a remote road in Sweden.

entry.title: Helen Keller Nailed It In This Quote
entry.content: It's as true today as ever!

entry.title: Why we love looking at horrifying scenes of death and disaster
entry.content: Humans aren't the only creatures who like staring at morbid disaster. What draws us to it?

entry.title: Today's Humans Ready to Love Tomorrow's Robots
entry.content: Robots and virtual companions can already push the emotional buttons of humans, and tomorrow's versions will only get better.

entry.title: Real Life Rapture: Who Goes, Who Stays?
entry.content: October 21, 2011 was a brisk autumn day, the temperature hovering around the mid-60s, at least in Southern California. U.S. stocks rallied to their highest levels in three months, anticipating a swift resolution to Europe’s debt crisis. Wishful thinking, but the day traders weren’t the only ones whose calculations were off. According to Christian futurists, October 21, 2011 was the day the world was supposed to end. For centuries, it’s been termed “The Rapture”.
